Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Structure-selective protein modification with dirhodium metallopeptide catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program is supporting the research of Professor Zachary Ball of Rice University. Professor Ball is developing a new concept for the proximity-based chemical modification of proteins through a new combination of supramolecular chemistry and organometallic catalysis. This approach results in catalytic activity based on shape and secondary structure rather than inherent functional group reactivity. Professor Ball's method will be used to characterize polypeptide binding interfaces, based on the ability of dirhodium metallopeptides to convert transient binding into covalent modification. Fleeting interactions between proteins govern numerous biological signaling processes, yet are challenging to study. The new approach may provide a conceptually novel alternative to traditional affinity-labeling and photo-affinity labeling, and potentially one that will be able to capture weaker and/or more transient protein-protein interactions.

This Rh-carbenoid labeling technique could have important applications in chemical biology, in the longer term, both to identify as yet unknown binding partners for a given probe ligand, and to potentially even begin to identify new cellular signaling or regulatory pathways. The project will serve as a platform to train future scientists, both through graduate student training and through affiliated teacher-training programs in local districts with significant populations of economically disadvantaged students and of minorities traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. Professor Ball will conduct a comprehensive teacher-training program consisting of instruction in chemistry and chemical education, research experience, and new curriculum development. Teachers will spend a summer in the PI's lab to conduct research and to develop inquiry-based lessons based on their research. Lesson plans will be disseminated through talks at regional ACS meetings, workshops for other high school teachers in Houston, and via the web.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI, Zachary Ball, and his lab have completed work under the CAREER research grant. This grant mechanism supported fundamental studies into the design of new reactions to alter the structure of natural proteins. By using molecular recognition and selective protein-peptide interactions, it is now possible to alter the chemical structure of natural proteins in a predictable manner, with completely new chemical functionality. Simple rhodium complexes induce this new chemistry.

In developing this new modification chemistry, the PI and his group also developed a variety of reactive biological probes and new imaging methods that are available to other researchers interested in protein chemistry, chemical biology, and medicinal chemistry. Studies also shed new light on how specific transition-metal complexes act in living organisms, providing new insights into the way metals get into cells, and the way they react and change chemical structure once inside. These studies also elucidated fundamental concepts for how organic structures and metals work in harmony to bind tightly to specific proteins on interest, providing a designed, unnatural analogue of natural metal-templated protein assemblies, such as proteins that block matrix metalloproteinase function.

Because the protein modification reactions studies can be directly tied to specific protein–protein interactions events, these studies provide a direct tool to identify and study diverse biological processes. Our studies identified a previously unknown binding site on an important cancer-causing protein, STAT3, and point the way for future efforts to control aberrant STAT3.

Efforts under this grant included extensive opportunities to share our work with the broader community, and to educate the next generation of scientists. Six high-school chemistry teachers worked on this project as part of an NSF teacher-training program, and Zachary Ball and his research group have been actively involved in secondary education at local Houston high schools.

The grant also provided training to four undergraduate students who began Ph.D. studies after completing their undergraduate work at Rice.  Two Ph.D. dissertations have been completed under the support of this grant, and four continuing Ph.D. students have worked on this project, and expect to complete their dissertations during 2018-2019.

Links to publications stemming from this work are available at http://ztb.rice.edu/.
